And then you see another date that represents the date of death. And in between those two dates, just a little dash, just a little dash, that's how many days we have. That's what our pilgrimage is. Moses would say in Psalm 90 that we live our days like a tale that is told, like a story. I don't know when the end comes in my story or in your story, but we know about stories, there's an ending. God, what do you have for us? What do you want with us? If you were to give me more days, weeks, months, years, decades, how will you use me? God, I want to be used for your honor and for your glory. He said, and so I kind of figured that we could start in Edinburgh, and we could start at 8.30 in the morning on Sunday, and we can be done by around 10, 10.15, and then we can jump in the car and we can either go north or south, depending on how God leads us, and we could have another church service from 11 to about 12.30. Then we're going to have lunch, then we're going to have an afternoon service, then we're going to jump in the car and we're going to go back to Edinburgh, so we can have an evening service. And then for the midweek, we're going to do one on Wednesday, and we're going to do one on Thursday. To God be the glory. We pray that God would give them strength to do that. But that's somebody that says, I want my life to amount to something. I want to impact eternity with my life. What a perspective. Jacob, he lived in Egypt for 17 years. They got a place, the best place, because they were in the will of God. Got provision. All their needs were taken care of. Phenomenal. But then he reflected on his pilgrimage. Let us take inventory. God, what are we doing? Why are we here? How are we impacting eternity? I want my life to count. Let's pray.
